data.text: A Bike Computer for Navigation: Any Recommendations?

What bike computers doing you people recommend for navigation (I'm not particularly worried about power meters, etc)? I've been using my phone with Komoot, but would rather save the phone battery for communication (novel idea I know)
Currently a Wahoo Bolt, but want to get the Roam. Use OS Maps on my phone as a backup as the GPS is pretty useless for rerouting or just needing a clearer view
data.author: Henk Kommers

data.text: I'm running Garmin 1030 plus and my mates just got a Hamerhead both seem to be up to the job...
data.author: Eamon Kavanagh

data.text: Anything with half decent mapping and routing capabilities will be compatible with power meters etc. I’m really happy with my Elemnt Bolt V2
data.author: James Stockton

data.text: Wahoo elemnt bolt
data.author: Jake May

data.text: Depends on your budget really, i run a Garmin 1030 plus and its excellent for route planning/following. Keep the phone out of the way in case of emergencies, nothing worse than going to use it and the battery's flat.
data.author: Andy Clarke

data.text: I went Garmin 530 as I didn’t want touch screen as it’s a pain in the winter with gloves.
data.author: Dale Warren

data.text: Another wahoo bolt user. Yes, it's black and white only, but battery life is brilliant. Mine's linked to komoot so I download my route's onto my phone as a backup.
data.author: Patrick Civil

data.text: Garmin edge 530 with clip on battery pack for extra long rides
data.author: Chris Roberts

data.text: Wahoo Bolt. I also have the Garmin 1030. For pure navigation the Bolt is easier to set up, navigation and more reliable than the Garmin. I would choose Wahoo over Garmin.
data.author: Steve Lindley

data.text: Garmin 1030 plus - works great. Larger full colour screen than everything else on the market. Helps the old eyes see the map better than the other offerings out there. Garmin also allows you to upload OS maps unlike the rivals where you are stuck with a very limited pre loaded map. Which is kinda important if you plan on going offroad away from urban areas as often you find the trail you are on isnt on the map... This in my view is where the wahoo falls down, the mapping is not very great once you are out of towns and cities and into the wilderness. A lot of the small singletrack trails just dont appear on the map..
data.author: Jim McNeil

data.text: Just got a Wahoo roam. So far so good, very easy to set up and use.
data.author: Aled Richards

data.text: I have a ELEMNT bolt too. Mostly trouble free travels. Excellent battery life. The small screen can be confusing in busy urban mapped areas but it will soon let you know if you’ve taken a wrong turn.
data.author: Paul Tozer

data.text: A handheld hiking Garmin on a mount. Runs on AA batteries you can buy literally anywhere in Europe. Not the most compact solution, but if you're weeks away from the nearest socket...
data.author: Pavel Bogolyubov

data.text: Pavel, different response to everyone one else and an interesting idea, as I'd like to do more hiking aswell
data.author: Terry Merry

data.text: I have both garmin etrex and elemnt bolt. The bolt has maps built in where as I needed to get so maps loaded as an extra on the etrex ( you might be able to load up open source ones). The bolt refresh rate is great ( the etrex can lag a bit). Battery pretty good. A plus for me is turn by turn with the bolt if you link to komoot and have the region your travelling unlocked. Love the fact that the etrex uses AA and is great for multi sport but the screen is pretty small and can be a difficult when your trying to see a large area in detail. Both are dead easy to load with routes with some mapping app, i use komoot and plotaroute. I used the etrex as my only bike computer for ages (the bike mount is pretty crap though) until wanting something that's a tad easier to use and fancied turn by turn. On thing that was a bit of a bugbear was the screen on the etrex doesn't auto rotate where as the bolt always aligns the map to your direction. That said will be off on a 5 day trip soon and will be taking both!!
data.author: Ian Shuttleworth

data.text: Yep, hiking is partly the point; I'm using it for everything else: hiking, kayaking, sailing... It's basically an all-rounder. Replaceable batteries are a huge bonus, too: it's so easy to stick a pair of AA rechargeables into the pocket, and you know you're good for more than a day just on that. I'd probably like to have a cycling-specific GPS, but I'm put off by the price and the battery life - enough for a day, but then you need a socket.
data.author: Pavel Bogolyubov

data.text: Mine is a GPSMap 62, about 10 years old and still going strong. There's a newer version I'd get if anything happened to mine. Open source, free maps. Routing function pretty bad, but I never use it anyway; the rest is pretty spot on.
data.author: Pavel Bogolyubov

data.text: Pavel, that's it. I'm looking multi day trips and wild camping, so I want something that will last without needing a socket
data.author: Terry Merry

data.text: That's probably the answer then. Don't get me wrong, I am not dissing the cycling ones - ideally, I'd have a Bolt or something like that for day rides, and a handheld for tours and other outdoor stuff, but if you want to have only one device that can do both, that's a handheld. Besides, I hardly ever use a GPS on day rides - I know local roads, within a 50-mile radius, well enough. If I do get lost, I can get the phone out. And I prefer riding without a computer always in sight - I'm doing it for pleasure, not performance. But that's just me.
data.author: Pavel Bogolyubov

data.text: Pavel I did my last one on NCN routes and as my phone died early I managed London to Eastbourne just using the NCN signage

data.text: I use a Garmin Explore, turned off all the sport metrics rubbish and just use it for nav, speed, distance, elevation. I connect it to a battery pack or solar panel for long/multi days. For hiking I use the etrex 30x, great for walking, but not good for cycling nav imo.
